sn16.6:4.1: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.
sn16.6:4.2: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha,
sn16.6:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn16.6:4.7: Either you or I should advise the mendicants
sn16.6:4.8: and give them a Dhamma talk.”
sn16.6:5.1: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to correct, having qualities that make them hard to correct. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
sn16.6:5.2: Take the monk called Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s pupil. He’s been competing in studies with the monk called Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s pupil. They say:
sn16.6:5.3: ‘Come on, monk, who can recite more? Who can recite better? Who can recite longer?’”
sn16.6:6.1: So the Buddha said to a certain monk:
sn16.6:6.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the monk called Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s pupil, and the monk called Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s pupil that
sn16.6:6.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks
sn16.6:7.1: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha,
sn16.6:7.2: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn16.6:7.4: “Is it really true, monks, that you’ve been competing in studies, saying:
sn16.6:7.5: ‘Come on, monk, who can recite more? Who can recite better? Who can recite longer?’”
sn16.6:7.7: “Have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this:
sn16.6:7.9: see who can recite more and better and longer’?”
sn16.6:7.11: “If you’ve never known me to teach the Dhamma like this, then what exactly do you know and see, you foolish men, that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training you’d compete in studies to
sn16.6:7.12: see who can recite more and better and longer?”
sn16.6:8.1: Then those monks bowed with their heads at the Buddha’s feet and said:
sn16.6:8.2: “We have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of us in that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we competed in studies to
sn16.6:8.3: see who can recite more and better and longer.
sn16.6:8.4: Please, sir, accept our mistake for what it is, so we will restrain ourselves in future.”
sn16.6:9.1: “Indeed, monks, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.
sn16.6:9.3: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
sn16.6:9.4: For it is growth in the training of the noble one to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
